title: Request: Promote a new version to stable
author: sdz2
body_snippet:
Please consider releasing new builds: stable, preview, and nightly.

Consider branching from nightly then thoroughly testing all features.

The latest stable and preview versions are over four years old.  The RDP in v1.76.20 (stable) and v1.77.1 (preview) both still use the old RDP Automatic Resizing method, which takes 15 seconds and shows the Reconnecting dialog.

The RDP resizing works correctly in v1.77.3.1784-NB (nightly) Portable, but the build is full of other bugs: settings not sav...

comments.snippet:
@sdz2: I am happy that I am not alone! :)

I have done a ticket 2020-05-25 about it:
- https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/1765

Latest stable version is 1.76.20 (2019-04-12):
- https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/releases/tag/v1.76.20

And there are several CVEs in the latest current stable version:
- https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues?q=is%3Aissue+cve

Linked to:
- https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/1765
- https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/i...
comments.author: Neustradamus

comments.snippet:
i dream of a day that there is a new release.  i personally think that they should've shifted the branch to version 2 for the major overhaul and kept releasing minor versions of v1 for bug fixes, security etc. 

4 years is a VERY long time ...

Edit: Reference for far too much done in a minor version: https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/projects/3
comments.author: Laim

comments.snippet: @Laim: Maybe the team has done a deal with several hacker teams to keep a software with CVEs.
comments.author: Neustradamus

comments.snippet:
Hello,
last years I only use putty, but I think its a good thing to use a tool like this. I found https://github.com/1Remote/1Remote and there I  found this project, but which project is better? 1Remote have a new version but only one developer, this project have a 4 years old stable version but, I think, more developers?
comments.author: BurtGummer

comments.snippet:
Hi,
I don't think it's about the number of developers. For example, [wezterm](https://wezfurlong.org/wezterm/index.html) is done by a single person and has a very active user base as well as regular releases.
What most people have a problem with (I think) is:
- the amount of time its taken from the last release
- no periodical (monthly, weekly) releases whatsoever
- promises that have not been kept

Just my 2ct

Regards,
J.

comments.snippet: hello, just back after holidays so sorry for delayed responce, new release is planed to september, delay due a lot of changes going in local code (cant commit due to much changes) but working towards such, so be patient, one of change what mR will store settings in local db. (Encrypted, secured) another one - we dont load connections data into tree, only pointer to data source, that helps to avoid sensitive data leak reported in several cve for older versions what i dont want to support (to much...
comments.author: Kvarkas

comments.snippet:
I think what's worth thinking about is what @Laim suggested here: https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/2474#issuecomment-1683229969.

Ambition and wanting to progress the project is a noble goal, but it should be done in a way that doesn't force you into a corner where you can't release for years because your working on a set of features. 

Opensource projects are a marathon not a race and one needs a strategy to deal with the demands of the project and at the very least address sec...

comments.snippet: I dont do release just to have release :) I am not interesting in increasing numbers, at same time i have a vision what and how product should be look like but acept what is not only coding is in my life so I am delaing with many other items and not only for this release so release will hapened this year for sure, as Russians says - speed is needed only then catching flees ;)

comments.snippet:
Welp, september came and went. And no release whatsoever. I was kind of hoping that @Kvarkas kept his word this time, but sadly this is not the case.
I know you have a lot to do @Kvarkas, but so do we and the whole world. And it is also OK to want big things with this project. But not keeping your word is very deplorable.
And because of this I have been asked by my boss to uninstall and stop using mRemoteNG from all our PCs and servers. This is such a great piece of software and I'm sad to hav...

comments.snippet:
Kvarkas wrote:
> I dont do release just to have release :) I am not interesting in increasing numbers

Nobody asked for a release just to have a release, so there is no need for such empty rhetoric. Please release to fix increasing number of security issues.

I highly recommend to think about [Xhanthi's comment](https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/2474#issuecomment-1706384846) a 2nd time. The idea is to have this project use [A successful Git branching model](https://nvie.com/post...

comments.snippet:
Don't get your hopes up. @Kvarkas already said that a new release would be coming [in september](https://github.com/mRemoteNG/mRemoteNG/issues/2474#issuecomment-1701291604), but like I said above, september came and went without any kind of update (you can even see that he lost github access for a few days/weeks in september).
So even if he says "soon" or "december" I wouldn't have a reason to believe him.
comments.author: JeanPluzo
savornicesei

comments.snippet:
@savornicesei 
I wasn't rude, but when I read, I saw that it's been more than 3 years just promising a new stable version and to this day the problems in the testing versions haven't stopped.

System promises, such as support for MySQL and it doesn't work, simple schema error, but there is no database schema updated for the testing version anywhere.

I wish I could help, but I don't have the necessary programming knowledge, so I'm still waiting.
